Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Intraoperative Mechanical Ventilation Strategies

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with patients undergoing major abdominal surgery at a tertiary care hospital.

Participants.evidence: patients undergoing major abdominal surgery at a tertiary care hospital

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a lung protective ventilation strategy with low tidal volumes (6-8 mL/kg) and PEEP of 5-10 cm H2O or a traditional ventilation strategy with higher tidal volumes (10-12 mL/kg) and zero PEEP.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effects of different intraoperative mechanical ventilation strategies on perioperative lung injury and surgical outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications, measured within 5 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the lung protective group and 100 to the traditional group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the lung protective group and 97 in the traditional group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The lung protective group showed a significant reduction in postoperative pulmonary complications (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the lung protective group and 1% of the traditional group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects being the most common.

Funding.evidence: Funding: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
